= Login Example =

Please read the [LoginExampleFeatureSpec Feature Specification] of the Login Example application. Implementations with different Flex SDKs (Flex 3.5, Flex 4.1 and Flex 4.5), mobile platforms (Google Android, Apple iOS TODO and !BlackBerry Tablet OS TODO), MVC Microarchitectures ([http://sourceforge.net/adobe/cairngorm Cairngorm 2.2.2],  [http://trac.puremvc.org/PureMVC_AS3/ PureMVC] TODO), IoC Microarchitectures ([http://www.spicefactory.org/parsley/ Parsley 2.4.1], [http://www.springactionscript.org/ Spring AS 1.1], [http://www.swizframework.org/ Swiz 1.3.1], [http://www.robotlegs.org/ Robotlegs 1.5.2], [http://mate.asfusion.com/ Mate 0.9.1]), Eventarchitectures ([https://github.com/robertpenner/as3-signals/wiki AS3-Signals]), Nanoarchitectures ([NanoarchitectureMVCb MVCb],  Presentation Model, Code Behind, Presenter, MVP TODO, Ctl, Cmd, [NanoarchitectureNoEvt NoEvt], [NanoarchitecturePInj PInj] ... etc.), [http://sourceforge.net/adobe/cairngorm/wiki/CairngormLibraries/ Cairngorm 3 Libraries] ([http://sourceforge.net/adobe/cairngorm/wiki/CairngormLibraries/#Validation Validation Library], [http://sourceforge.net/adobe/cairngorm/wiki/CairngormLibraries/#Task Task Library], [http://sourceforge.net/adobe/cairngorm/wiki/CairngormLibraries/#Observer Observer Library]), Continuous Integration and Deployment Tools (Maven, [http://flexmojos.sonatype.org/ Flexmojos] TODO, Ant with !FlexTask) and Testing frameworks ([http://flexunit.org/ FlexUnit 4.0]), Flex Automation ([http://www.riatest.com/ RIATest], [http://www.gorillalogic.com/flexmonkey FlexMonkey] ... etc.) are listed below. The code follows additional Flex coding conventions ([Flex3CodingConventions Flex 3], [Flex4CodingConventions Flex 4]). 

  * [LoginExample#Flex_3 Flex 3]
  * [LoginExample#Flex_4_(Halo) Flex 4 (Halo)]
  * [LoginExample#Flex_4_(Gumbo) Flex 4 (Gumbo)]
  * [LoginExample#Flex_4_(Hero) Flex 4 (Hero)]

== Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) ==

==== Why have you created the Login Example? ==== 
Please read my [MotivationLetter Motivation Letter].

==== What's a Nanoarchitecture? ==== 
Please read this page about [Nanoarchitecture Nanoarchitectures].

==== Which Microarchitecture has the best performance? ==== 
Don't know. Maybe somebody could create performance tests for it ;)

==== Which Microarchitecture do you prefer? ==== 
I am not making that decision for you. It is up to you to decide which one suites best to your needs.

==== Why haven't you choosen Microarchitectures like PureMVC, !SmartyPants or Flicc ... etc. for your Login Example? ==== 
I am thinking of adding other Microarchitectures, too. If they fit into the concept I will definitely add them. One issue I have with PureMVC and Robotlegs (without AS3-Signals) is that they are using the Mediator pattern for their views. This feels quiet massive when you want to work with !SkinnableComponents in Flex 4 (3 classes = Skin class + !SkinnableComponent + Mediator). If you have a good solution please [http://www.masuland.com?content=contact let me know]. Thanks!

==== Why do you have only so few Robotlegs and Mate examples for the Login Example? Are you biased? ==== 
No! I just have started adding Robotlegs and Mate examples to the Login Example.

==== Which Nanoarchitectures do you prefer? ==== 
For Flex 4 applications, I recommend, you should have a look at the [LoginExample#Flex_4_(Gumbo)_with_MVCpshStoTsk_PInjNoEvt Login Example for Flex 4 (Gumbo) with MVCpshStoTsk_PInjNoEvt] Nanoarchitectures. For Flex 3 applications, consider to use the [NanoarchitectureMVCb "Model - View - Code Behind" (MVCb)] Nanoarchitecture as shown in the [LoginExample#Flex_4_(Halo)_with_MVCbCtl LoginExample for Flex 4 (Halo) with MVCbCtl].

==== How can I migrate my Flex 3 application to a Flex 4 application? ====
Please read this [MigrationFromFlex3ToFlex4 Flex 3 to Flex 4 Migration Guide].
